fileDesc.extent: Approx. 27 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 8 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 24917)

Reproduction of original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2007-08 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2010-02 John LattaText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: Farmer. 1614.
div.p: Cut or Prime Vines in Februarie, or March, the Moone increaſing in light, and in Taurus, Virgo, or Libra.
Geld Cattell in the Wane of the Moone, chiefly if ſhe be in Aries, Sagittarius, or in Capricome.
Sheare Sheepe from the Change to the Full.
Poule thy Head, and Shaue thy Beard, when the Moone is in Libra, Sagittarius, Aquarius, or Piſces, chiefly from the firſt Quarter to the Full Moone.

div.head: Here doth follow a compendious Regiſter of all the moſt principall High-waies throughout Ireland; very meete & neceſſarie for all that ſhall haue occaſion to trauell into any place of this Kingdome: and firſt of the way from Dublin to Waterford by the Sea ſide, and ſo from thence to Corke.
div.p: FRom Dublin to Brey x. myles, From Brey to New Caſtle viii. myles, from Newcaſtle to Wicklow vi. myles, from Wicklow to Arcklow xii myles, from Arcklow to Glaſcarig xii. myles, from Glaſcarig to Weirford xii. myles, from Weirford to Roſſe xiiii myles, from Roſſe to Waterford viii. myles: In all from Dublin 82. myles.

From Waterford to Kil-macktomas xii. myles, from Kil-ma ••
tomas to Dungaruan viii. myles, from Dungaruan to Yoghell x. myles, from Yoghell to Cor-abbey xviii. myles, from Cor-abbey to Corke x. myles: In all from Dublin 132. myles.

div.head: The way from Dublin to Gowran, and ſo from thence to all the chiefe places in Munſter.
div.p:
FRom Dublin to the Naſe xii. myles, from the Naſe to Kil-cullin vi. myles, from Kil-cullin to Caſtell Dearmot ix. myles,
from Caſtell-Dearmot to Carlagh v. myles, from Carlagh to Laghlin v. miles, from Laghlin to Gowran v. miles: in all from Dublin 42. miles.

p.hi: This Paragraffe ¶ ſhall giue notice of the way to many other places in Mounſter. And firſt to Waterford.

div.p: ¶ FRom Gowran to Thomaſtowne v. miles, from Thomaſtowne to Waterford xv. miles: in all from Dublin 62. miles.

div.head: The way from Gowran to Yoghell.
div.p: ¶ FRom Gowran to Knock-togher viii. miles, from Knock-togher • o Carrig viii. miles, from Carrig to Dungaruan xii. miles, from Dungaruan to Yoghell x. miles: in all from Dublin 80. miles.

div.head: The way from Gowran to Corke, and ſo to Baltimore and further Weſt.
div.p: ¶ FRom Gowran to B • nnets Bridge iii. miles, from Bennets. Bridge to Kelles iii. miles, from K • lles to C • alagh iiii. miles, from C • ala • h to K • lchaſhell 〈◊〉 . miles, from 〈◊〉 ſh • ll to Cloa •• m • ll o • m • les▪ from Cloanemell to L • ſhmore xii. miles, from Liſhmore • o Caſtel-L • ha • e viii miles, from Ca •• el Lehane to Cor • e xii. miles: in all from Dublin 92. miles▪ From Corke to Mahowne-bridge x. m • les, from Mahowne-bridge to Tymolegue viii. m • les, from Tymolegue • o Roſſe viii. miles, from Roſſe to Baltimore viii miles, from B • ltimore to Caſt • l-hauen viii. miles, from Caſt • l-hauen to Leamig • l • a • e viii. miles: in all from Dublin 140. miles.

div.head: The way from Gowran to Caſhell, and ſo to Dinghan I. couſhe.
div.p:
¶ From Gowran to Benne • s. Bridge iii. miles, fr • m Benne • s. Bridge to Call • n vi. miles, from Callon to Killan • le vii. in les, from • llanale to C • ſhill vii. wiles. from Caſhell to Typprrarie vi. m • les from T • ppererie to Emil • vi. m • les. from Emibe to kilmallacke vi m • les, from Kilm▪
• ocke to Bollingarute • mil • s, from Ballingarr e • o New-Caſtell vi. in les, fr • m N • w-Caſtell to Bruſtina • h viii. in l • s, from Bruſtinagh to Ilandltierie vii miles, from Iland-kier • e to Ea ••• -maine viii m • les, from Catel-maine to Ding • an Ico • ſhe • vi. miles: in a • l from Dlib • n 133 miles.

div.head: the way from Gowran to Limbricke, and ſo againe to Dinghan lcouſhe.
div.p: ¶ FRom Gowran to Caſhill, as before xriii. miles, from Caſhe • l to Sallahode viii. mil • s, from Sallahode to Ballini • i • miles, from Balli-ni • e ro Car • ighkenbſh vii in les, from Car • igkenl • ſh to Limbricke v. miles: in all from D • bl • 89. miles.

From Limbricke to Adare vii. miles, from Adare • o Raki • l •
• . mile, from R. k • e • e to Ardah iii. miles. from Ardah to Moniſterfea •• ix miles from Maniſterea ••• o Trali • xii. nules, frō Tralie to D • nghan Icouſhe xxi. miles: in all from Limbricke 50. miles.

div.head: Aſoorter way from Dublin to Limbricke, not much vſed.
div.p: From Dublin to Ma • noth x. miles, from Maynotb to Ciancurrie v miles, from Cla • c •••• to Caſ • el-Carberi • v m • les, from Caſ • rl-Catherie to Phliptowne • . miles, from Philptowne to Be •• bay-cer •••• ll xiiii. m ••• s, from B • ſhbuy- ••• rec • ll to Bir vi miles, from Birro Ballinggarrie • iii. myles, from Ballingar • ie to Ennagh-more viii. miles, from Engi-mor • to Limbrikce xvi. miles: in all from Dublin 82. miles.

div.head: The way from Kinſale to Limbricke, and ſo to Galway.
div.p: FRom Kinſale to Corke x. myles, from Corke to Mallow xii. myles, from Mallow to Kil-mallocke xii. myles, from Kil-mallocke to Limbricke xii. myles, from Limbricke to Quin xii. myles, from Quin to Barnacoyle vi. myles, from Barnacoyle to Gortinchigorie vi. myles, from Gortinchigorie to Kilcolgan vi. myles, from Kilcolgan to Galway vi. myles: in all from Kinſale 82. myles.

div.head: The way from Waterford to Limbricke, and ſo to Galway.
div.p: FRom Waterford to Carrig xii. myles, from Carrig to Cloanemell viii. myles, from Cloanemell to the Bridge of Goalin x. myles, from Goalin to Sallahode vi. myles, from Sallahode to Limbricke, as aboue in the way from Gowran to Limbricke: and ſo to Galway, as aboue in the way from Kinſale: In all from Waterford 88. myles.

div.head: The way from Dublin to Aloane, and ſo to Galway.
div.p: FRom Dublin to Trim xx. myles, from Trim to Abuye v. miles, from Abuye to Mullengar xv. myles, from Mullengar to Ballimore x. m • les, from Ballimore to Aloane x • . myles, from Aloane to Ballenſtoe x. myles, from Ballenſtoe to Kilconell vi. myles, from Kilconell to Athenrie xii. myles, from Athenrie to Galway viii. myles.

div.head: Another ſhorter way from Dublin to Aloane, and ſo to Balliſhennan, and to the Derrie.
div.p:
TAke the ſhotcer way from Dublin to Limbricke, as before, vntill you come to Caſtel-Carbetie, then from thence to Edenderr • e • i. myles, frō E • enderrie to Moniſter-orie one myle, from Moniſter-orie to Togher-Croghan iiii. myles, from Togher-Croghan to Cloan-Iriell ii. myles, from Cloan-Iriell to Barnan one myle, from Barnan to Kil-Cloanfart one myle, from Kil-Cloanfart
ouer the Enian to Kil-beggan iiii. myles, from Kil-beggan to Aloane xiiii. myles, from Aloane to Roſcomon xii. myles, from Roſcomon to Tulſke viii. myles, ☞ from Tulſke to the Abbey of Boyle xii. myles, from the Abbey of Boyle to Ballimote x. myles, from Ballimote to Slygo x. myles, from Slygo to Bundrowes xv. myles, from Bundrowes to Balli-ſhemian v. myles, ſrom Balli-ſhemian to Downagall x. myles, from Downagall to Caſtel-lifford xrv. myles, from Caſtel-lifford to Derrie x. myles: in all from Dublin 162. myles.

div.head: The way from Galway to Balliſhenan, and to the Derrie.
div.p: FRom Galway to Clare iiii myles, from Clare to the Bridge of Ballimoy xvii. myles, from the Bridge of Ballimoy to Tulſke viii miles, from the Tulſke to Balliſhenan, and the Derrie, as aboue at this marke ☞ from Tulſke. &c.

div.head: The way from Dublin, directly to Balliſhenan.
div.p: FRom Dublin to Nauan xx. miles, from Nauan to Kelles vii. miles, from Kelles to Cauan xx. miles. ¶ from Cauan to Balterbert vii miles, from Balterbert to Balliſhenan by Water xxx. miles▪ in all from Dublin 84. miles. But if you will trauell all by land, then goe from Cauan to Clunneys xii. miles, from Clunneys to Liſh neſkeaghe viii. miles, from Liſh neſkeaghe to Iumſkilling ix. miles, from Iumſkilling to Balliſhenan xx. miles: in all from Dublin this way 96. miles.

div.head: The way from Dublin to the Derrie.
div.p:
FRom D • bl • n to Swords vi m • les, from Swords to Balrudd • rie vi. m • les, from Balrudderie to Droghedah viii. miles▪ f • om Dr • gh •• ah to D •• leare vi. miles, from Dunleare to Dund • lke x. miles, from Dun •• lke to the Newrie viii. miles, ¶ from Newrie to Mount-Nerreis viii. miles, from Mount-Norreis to A • dmagh 〈◊〉 . miles, from Ardmagh to Cha • l • mount v. miles, from Cha • l • m • unt to Dunganan v. miles, from Dunganan to Omey xvi • . miles, from Omey to Newtowne vi. Miles, from Newtowne
to Lifford vi. miles, from Lifford to D • r • fex. miles: in all from D • blm 110. miles.

div.head: The way from Newrie to Carigfergus.
div.p:
¶ FRom Newrie to D • ummore xvi. miles, from D • mmore to Liſh-negat viii. miles, from L • ſh-negar to H • lſ • orow vi. miles, from H • ſborow to Belfaſt two miles, from Belfaſt to Car
• igf •• gus viii. miles.

div.head: From Newrie to Carigfergus through Locale.
div.p: ¶ FRom Newrie to Dundrum xvi. miles, from Dundrum to Downe v. miles, from Downe to 〈◊〉 v. miles, ouer the Water i. miles, from the Wate • s ſi • e to Blackſtaffe vi miles, from Blackſtaffe to Gray Abbey v. miles, from Gray Abbey to Newtowne iiii miles, from Newtowne to the Foord of B • lfaſt vii. miles, from thence to Carrigfergus vi • i. miles.

div.head: The way from Newrie to Colerane.
div.p: ¶ FRom Newrie to Inniſ-langhlin xvi. m • les, from Inniſlanghlin to Autrim xii. miles, from Au •• im to Kelles vi. miles, from K • lles to Cloghmahharigonie vi. miles▪ from Cloghmahharigonie to B • lly-monie vi. miles, from Bally-monie to Celerane.

div.head: The way from Carrigfergus to Colerane.
div.p: FRom Carrigfergus to K • ll • s xi. miles, from Kelles as before▪ &c.

div.head: The Way from Carrigfergus to Colerane by the Sea ſide.
div.p: FRom Carrigfergus to Gl •• arme • ii. miles, from Gl •• arme to D • wnanenie x. miles, from 〈◊〉 to Downluce viii. miles, from Downl • ce v. miles to Co •• ane.

div.head: Of the moſt principall Fayres and Marts, as they are vſually holden in this Kingdome of Ireland; and alſo of many new Fayres, lately erected by Patent, added in this yeare.

table.head: Of ſuch Fayres as are guided onely by the moueable Feaſtes of the yeare.
